user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueueDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /* Try to delete and unlink the queue */
    if (mq_close(impl->id) != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_QueueDelete Error during mq_close(). errno = %d (%s)\n", errno, strerror(errno));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they either already use const-qualified pointers or do not involve pointer types. Specifically: the function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token; OS_ObjectIndexFromToken accepts a const OS_object_token_t *; the use of &(tok) in the macro passes a const pointer to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken; and there are no other pointer variables or pointer-returning calls in the shown code that could be made to point to const-qualified types. The listed fragments are the locations where a non-const pointer is obtained or declared for an object that is not modified in this function and thus should be investigated for possible const-qualification under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
